content: The "Gasoline Price Reduction and Refinery Tax Fairness Act of 2004" aims to reduce the United States' dependence on foreign energy sources by 45% by 2014 through conservation, efficiency, alternative sources, technology development, and domestic production. The Gasoline Price Reduction and Refinery Tax Fairness Act of 2004 aims to reduce US dependence on foreign energy sources through various means. Section 502 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to define oil and gas exploration and production activities. Additionally, the creation of the Office of Federal Energy Project Coordination is proposed. The Gasoline Price Reduction and Refinery Tax Fairness Act of 2004 proposes the establishment of the Office of Federal Energy Project Coordination within the Executive Office of the President. The Office will consist of experts from relevant Federal agencies to coordinate and expedite Federal decisions on energy projects, providing an annual report to Congress with recommendations for improving the permitting process. The Gasoline Price Reduction and Refinery Tax Fairness Act of 2004 proposes the establishment of the Office of Federal Energy Project Coordination within the Executive Office of the President to coordinate and expedite Federal decisions on energy projects. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, will review current Federal onshore oil and gas leasing practices, including accepting or rejecting offers, appeals processes, and surface use plans of operation. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture will review Federal onshore oil and gas leasing practices, including recommendations for improving the process and addressing site-specific concerns. A report to Congress on actions taken under Executive Order No. 13212 and plans to improve the leasing program is due within 180 days of enactment. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT OF FEDERAL OIL AND GAS LEASING PROGRAMS. To ensure timely action on oil and gas leases and permits, the Secretary of the Interior must comply with environmental regulations, improve consultation with States and the public, and enhance information management. Additionally, best management practices will be developed within 18 months to improve the administration of onshore oil activities. The Secretary of the Interior aims to improve the onshore oil and gas leasing program under the Mineral Leasing Act by ensuring timely action on leases and permits. Best management practices will be developed, and specific timeframes for processing leases and applications will be set forth in proposed regulations within 180 days. The Secretary aims to improve enforcement of oil and gas activities, including deadlines for approving resource management plans, lease applications, and surface use plans. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2005 through 2008 to carry out the outlined actions. SEC. 7. CONSULTATION REGARDING OIL AND GAS LEASING ON PUBLIC LAND. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture must create a memorandum of understanding within 180 days of this Act's enactment regarding oil and gas leasing on public lands and National Forest System lands. The memorandum will establish procedures for timely processing of lease applications, surface use plans, and permits to drill. The amendment made by section 10 establishes timelines, eliminates duplication of effort, and ensures consistent and coordinated lease stipulations. A joint data retrieval system will be established by the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to track applications and requests related to the oil and gas leasing program. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture will establish a joint Geographic Information System mapping system within 2 years to track surface resource values and process surface use plans and permits for drilling. SEC. 8. ESTIMATES OF OIL AND GAS RESOURCES UNDERLYING ONSHORE FEDERAL LAND. Section 604 of the Energy Act of 2000 is amended to include assessment of restrictions and impediments to resource development on federal land, such as delays in granting leases and post-lease restrictions on development. The Energy Act of 2000 is amended to assess restrictions on resource development on federal land, including transportation and quantity limitations. The Secretary of Energy will conduct periodic assessments of economically recoverable resources using various parameters. The Secretary of the Interior will apply the same assessment methodology across all geological provinces and areas. The Energy Act of 2000 is amended to assess restrictions on resource development on federal land, including transportation and quantity limitations. The Secretary of Energy will conduct periodic assessments of economically recoverable resources using various parameters. The Secretary of the Interior will apply a consistent assessment methodology across all geological provinces, areas, and regions for national geological assessments. SEC. 9. COMPLIANCE WITH EXECUTIVE ORDER 13211; ACTIONS CONCERNING REGULATIONS AFFECTING ENERGY SUPPLY. SEC. 9 requires Federal agencies to comply with Executive Order No. 13211 before taking actions affecting domestic energy resources on Federal land. The Secretary of Energy will provide guidance on what constitutes a significant adverse effect. A memorandum of understanding between the Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture will implement these requirements. Section 17 of the Mineral Leasing Act is amended to include deadlines for consideration of permit applications. The Secretary must notify the applicant within 10 days if the application is complete or missing information. Within 30 days of a complete application, the Secretary must issue the permit or defer the decision. The Secretary can defer a decision on a permit and provide the applicant with steps to obtain the permit. If the applicant receives notice of deferred application, they have 2 years to complete all requirements, including those for compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act. If the applicant meets the requirements within the specified period, the Secretary will issue the permit. The Secretary must issue a decision on a permit within 10 days of completing requirements, or deny the permit if requirements are not met. Field offices must report quarterly on permit applications received and their disposition. SEC. 11. ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS. Federal agencies must analyze the impact of gasoline production rules on supply to avoid increasing reliance on foreign oil sources. SEC. 12. ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION FOR REFINERY MACHINERY. SEC. 12. ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION FOR REFINERY MACHINERY. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include refinery machinery for accelerated depreciation. Effective for property placed in service after December 31, 2004. SEC. 13. REFINERY PERMITTING PROCESS. Federal agencies must approve or reject refinery applications within 180 days, providing reasons for rejection if necessary.
